elements.content: A new 3D metal–organic framework Ca-SBF based on a zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxocluster and 9,9′-spirobi­[9H-fluorene]-2,2′,7,7′-tetracarboxylic acid was obtained and exhibited flu topology. Ca-SBF underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a slight structure shrinkage. Activated Ca-SBF showed permanent porosity and CO2 adsorption properties. A Ca-SBF-modified quartz crystal microbalance sensor demonstrated selective response to toluene vapor.
elements.clean_text: A new 3D metal-organic framework Ca-SBF based on a zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxocluster and 9,9'-spirobi[9H-fluorene]-2,2',7,7'-tetracarboxylic acid was obtained and exhibited flu topology. Ca-SBF underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a slight structure shrinkage. Activated Ca-SBF showed permanent porosity and CO2 adsorption properties. A Ca-SBF-modified quartz crystal microbalance sensor demonstrated selective response to toluene vapor.

elements.content: A new 3D metal−organic framework Ca-SBF based on a zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxocluster and 9,9′-spirobi­[9H-fluorene]-2,2′,7,7′-tetracarboxylic acid was obtained and exhibited flu topology. Ca-SBF underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a slight structure shrinkage. Activated Ca-SBF showed permanent porosity and CO2 adsorption properties. A Ca-SBF-modified quartz crystal microbalance sensor demonstrated selective response to toluene vapor.
elements.clean_text: A new 3D metal-organic framework Ca-SBF based on a zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxocluster and 9,9'-spirobi[9H-fluorene]-2,2',7,7'-tetracarboxylic acid was obtained and exhibited flu topology. Ca-SBF underwent a single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a slight structure shrinkage. Activated Ca-SBF showed permanent porosity and CO2 adsorption properties. A Ca-SBF-modified quartz crystal microbalance sensor demonstrated selective response to toluene vapor.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively investigated as a new and emerging class of porous materials over the past two decades. Its broad application prospects in a wide variety of fields have been demonstrated by gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and chemical sensing. MOF-based chemical-sensing materials have received great attentions in recent years due to their exceptional structure diversity and tunability. The sensitivity and selectivity of MOF-based chemical sensors are highly dependent on the porous nature of sensory materials, which includes the pore geometry and interfacial interactions between analyte molecules and the framework. The judicious selection of nodes and linkers is critical for controlling the pore geometry and functionality of MOFs.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been extensively investigated as a new and emerging class of porous materials over the past two decades. Its broad application prospects in a wide variety of fields have been demonstrated by gas storage and separation, heterogeneous catalysis, and chemical sensing. MOF-based chemical-sensing materials have received great attentions in recent years due to their exceptional structure diversity and tunability. The sensitivity and selectivity of MOF-based chemical sensors are highly dependent on the porous nature of sensory materials, which includes the pore geometry and interfacial interactions between analyte molecules and the framework. The judicious selection of nodes and linkers is critical for controlling the pore geometry and functionality of MOFs.

elements.content: 9,9′-Spirobi­[9H-fluorene] (SBF), an ideal rigid building unit, has been successfully incorporated into several 2D MOFs by ligand symmetry modulation, showing intriguing structures and gas-adsorption properties. However, 3D SBF-based MOFs are seldom reported probably due to their tendency to form strong π–π interactions between aromatic rings. Evidently, the construction of 3D SBF-based MOFs by overcoming or weakening the π–π interactions remains a challenge and requires careful examination of the cations or cation clusters. For fine-tuning of the pore geometry and internal host–guest interactions, we select 9,9′-spirobi­[9H-fluorene]-2,2′,7,7′-tetracarboxylic acid (H 4 L) and Ca2+ ions to construct 3D SBF-based MOFs. H 4 L, a tetratopic carboxylate, is 3D and fully extended in nature, acting as a 4-connected tetrahedral linker. Ca2+ ions, with plenty of coordination modes, could adapt to any structure adjustment and facilitate the formation of 3D frameworks by the generation of different types of clusters.
elements.clean_text: 9,9'-Spirobi[9H-fluorene] (SBF), an ideal rigid building unit, has been successfully incorporated into several 2D MOFs by ligand symmetry modulation, showing intriguing structures and gas-adsorption properties. However, 3D SBF-based MOFs are seldom reported probably due to their tendency to form strong π-π interactions between aromatic rings. Evidently, the construction of 3D SBF-based MOFs by overcoming or weakening the π-π interactions remains a challenge and requires careful examination of the cations or cation clusters. For fine-tuning of the pore geometry and internal host-guest interactions, we select 9,9'-spirobi[9H-fluorene]-2,2',7,7'-tetracarboxylic acid (H  4  L) and Ca2+ ions to construct 3D SBF-based MOFs. H  4  L, a tetratopic carboxylate, is 3D and fully extended in nature, acting as a 4-connected tetrahedral linker. Ca2+ ions, with plenty of coordination modes, could adapt to any structure adjustment and facilitate the formation of 3D frameworks by the generation of different types of clusters.

elements.content: Among a diverse range of sensing technologies, a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) is attractive and is widely employed due to its low-cost, portability, sensitivity, and stability. A QCM transducer is a weight-detectable device, sensing small changes in the vibrational frequency induced by weight changes of the analyte. Several researchers have demonstrated the detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by using MOF-modified QCM sensors, and VOCs could be recognized by shape, size, and weak intermolecular interactions in the regular pore of MOFs. The factors that influence the performance of MOFmodified QCM sensors are yet to be elucidated systematically. We herein report a new 3D SBF-based MOF Ca-SBF with flu topology that could undergo a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC–SC) transformation in methanol and show permanent porosity and toluene-sensing properties based on a QCM sensor.
elements.clean_text: Among a diverse range of sensing technologies, a quartz crystal microbalance (QCM) is attractive and is widely employed due to its low-cost, portability, sensitivity, and stability. A QCM transducer is a weight-detectable device, sensing small changes in the vibrational frequency induced by weight changes of the analyte. Several researchers have demonstrated the detection of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) by using MOF-modified QCM sensors, and VOCs could be recognized by shape, size, and weak intermolecular interactions in the regular pore of MOFs. The factors that influence the performance of MOFmodified QCM sensors are yet to be elucidated systematically. We herein report a new 3D SBF-based MOF Ca-SBF with flu topology that could undergo a single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) transformation in methanol and show permanent porosity and toluene-sensing properties based on a QCM sensor.

elements.content: H 4 L was synthesized in two steps according to a well-established method (Scheme S1). Tetraacylation of SBF, followed by hypobromite oxidation, gave rise to H 4 L as a white solid. The attempt to synthesize H 4 L via alkaline hydrolysis of 2,2′,7,7′-tetracyano-9,9′-spirobi­[9H-fluorene] failed due to solubility problems. Ca-SBF was solvothermally synthesized by mixing Ca­(NO3)2·4H2O and H 4 L in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 100 °C for about 2 days. Ca-SBF could be formulated as [Ca2L­(DMF)2]·2DMF, referring to the results of single-crystal X-ray structure analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text: H  4  L was synthesized in two steps according to a well-established method (Scheme S1). Tetraacylation of SBF, followed by hypobromite oxidation, gave rise to H  4  L as a white solid. The attempt to synthesize H  4  L via alkaline hydrolysis of 2,2',7,7'-tetracyano-9,9'-spirobi[9H-fluorene] failed due to solubility problems. Ca-SBF was solvothermally synthesized by mixing Ca(NO3)2⋅4H2O and H  4  L in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) at 100 °C for about 2 days. Ca-SBF could be formulated as [Ca2L(DMF)2]⋅2DMF, referring to the results of single-crystal X-ray structure analysis, thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis shows that Ca-SBF crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca (Table S1). The framework of Ca-SBF is constructed by the linkage of zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxoclusters and SBF ligands. In the unique calcium cluster (a), there are two crystallographically independent septacoordinated Ca2+ ions: one takes a distorted capped octahedral geometry (Ca1; b), and the other adopts a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (Ca2; b). They connect each other by edge-sharing to form a zigzag-shaped cluster (c). The cluster is coordinated by 16 O atoms from eight ligands and 6 O atoms from terminal DMF or H2O, with Ca–O distances from 2.261(4) to 2.854(3) Å, a Ca1···Ca2 distance of 3.630 (1) Å, a Ca1···Ca1 distance of 4.176 (1) Å, and a Ca2···Ca2 distance of 10.856 (2) Å. Calcium oxoclusters lie along the b axis with two orientations (Figure S6a). To the best of our knowledge, zigzag-shaped tetranuclear oxoclusters have seldom been reported for Ca2+ ions. Each oxocluster is linked to its neighbors by eight ligands (d), and each ligand bridges four oxoclusters via carboxylate groups in μ2(syn–syn), μ2(syn–anti), and η2modes (e) to form a 3D noninterpenetrating framework (f). The framework could be described as a 4,8-connected net with flu (CaF2) topology (g). In an alternative description, the crystal packing of Ca-SBF could be considered to be an AB type of layered packing with rectangular grids propagated along the ac plane and further held together by calcium oxoclusters. In the AB arrangement, the layer slips away from one another to the corner of the rectangular grid, and edge-to-edge interactions between aromatic rings in neighboring layers have been observed (Figure S6b). Due to the deviation of the AB stacking, 1D channels are found along the b axis. The solvent-accessible volumes are about 25% and 45% of the total crystal volume before and after the removal of terminal DMF, as calculated by PLATON.
elements.clean_text: Single-crystal X-ray structure analysis shows that Ca-SBF crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbca (Table S1). The framework of Ca-SBF is constructed by the linkage of zigzag-shaped tetranuclear calcium oxoclusters and SBF ligands. In the unique calcium cluster (a), there are two crystallographically independent septacoordinated Ca2+ ions: one takes a distorted capped octahedral geometry (Ca1; b), and the other adopts a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (Ca2; b). They connect each other by edge-sharing to form a zigzag-shaped cluster (c). The cluster is coordinated by 16 O atoms from eight ligands and 6 O atoms from terminal DMF or H2O, with Ca-O distances from 2.261(4) to 2.854(3) Å, a Ca1⋅⋅⋅Ca2 distance of 3.630 (1) Å, a Ca1⋅⋅⋅Ca1 distance of 4.176 (1) Å, and a Ca2⋅⋅⋅Ca2 distance of 10.856 (2) Å. Calcium oxoclusters lie along the b axis with two orientations (Figure S6a). To the best of our knowledge, zigzag-shaped tetranuclear oxoclusters have seldom been reported for Ca2+ ions. Each oxocluster is linked to its neighbors by eight ligands (d), and each ligand bridges four oxoclusters via carboxylate groups in μ2(syn-syn), μ2(syn-anti), and η2modes (e) to form a 3D noninterpenetrating framework (f). The framework could be described as a 4,8-connected net with flu (CaF2) topology (g). In an alternative description, the crystal packing of Ca-SBF could be considered to be an AB type of layered packing with rectangular grids propagated along the ac plane and further held together by calcium oxoclusters. In the AB arrangement, the layer slips away from one another to the corner of the rectangular grid, and edge-to-edge interactions between aromatic rings in neighboring layers have been observed (Figure S6b). Due to the deviation of the AB stacking, 1D channels are found along the b axis. The solvent-accessible volumes are about 25% and 45% of the total crystal volume before and after the removal of terminal DMF, as calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: Structure illustration of Ca-SBF: (a) unique calcium oxocluster; (b) capped octahedral geometry of Ca1 and pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry of Ca2; (c) zigzag-shaped oxocluster; (d) 8-connected oxocluster; (e) 4-connected ligand; (f) 3D framework viewed along the b axis; (g) flu topology.
elements.clean_text: 1  Structure illustration of Ca-SBF: (a) unique calcium oxocluster; (b) capped octahedral geometry of Ca1 and pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry of Ca2; (c) zigzag-shaped oxocluster; (d) 8-connected oxocluster; (e) 4-connected ligand; (f) 3D framework viewed along the b axis; (g) flu topology.

elements.content: To evaluate the porosity of Ca-SBF, a solvent-exchange procedure has been applied for activation. When crystals of Ca-SBF were left undisturbed in methanol for several days, they underwent a SC–SC transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a formula of [Ca2 L(CH3OH)2(H2O)2]·CH3OH·4H2O. Fortunately, crystals of Ca-SBF-1 were suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the crystal structure of Ca-SBF-1 was successfully resolved. This would be beneficial for a deep understanding of structural changes after the activation procedure. The space group of Ca-SBF-1 was retained as Pbca, but the cell parameters changed after SC–SC transformation (Table S1). Ca-SBF-1 revealed a shortening in the a (from 21.40 to 20.01 Å) and b (from 17.52 to 17.36 Å) axes and an elongation in the c (from 21.43 to 22.40 Å) axis. A shrinkage of the cell volume (from 8036 to 7780 Å3) was also observed. A careful structural examination and a comparison of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 suggested that structure deformation was reflected in two aspects. One is a small amount of distortion over the spirobifluorene ring, with a change of the dihedral angle from 89.5 to 87.4° (a). The other is a significant change in the coordination geometry of the Ca2+ ions. In the new calcium oxocluster, hexacoordinated Ca1 takes a distorted octahedral geometry, and octacoordinated Ca2 exhibits a distorted dodecahedral geometry (b). Much longer Ca···Ca distances were observed, i.e., Ca1···Ca2 distances from 3.630(1) to 3.715(2) Å, Ca1···Ca1 distances from 4.176(1) to 4.318(2) Å, and Ca2···Ca2 distances from 10.856(2) to 11.163(3) Å. The elongated oxocluster could be considered as two separate Ca2+ dimers, and with this new node, the whole framework could be described as an infinite 3D 5,5-connected 2-nodal net, which represents a new topology with a point symbol {45.65} (Figure S7). The solvent-accessible volume was reduced from 45% (Ca-SBF) to 39% (Ca-SBF-1), suggesting a slight structure shrinkage. The aperture sizes of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 were calculated as 5.47 and 5.27 Å by Poreblazer (Table S2).
elements.clean_text: To evaluate the porosity of Ca-SBF, a solvent-exchange procedure has been applied for activation. When crystals of Ca-SBF were left undisturbed in methanol for several days, they underwent a SC-SC transformation to form Ca-SBF-1 with a formula of [Ca2 L(CH3OH)2(H2O)2]⋅CH3OH⋅4H2O. Fortunately, crystals of Ca-SBF-1 were suitable for single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and the crystal structure of Ca-SBF-1 was successfully resolved. This would be beneficial for a deep understanding of structural changes after the activation procedure. The space group of Ca-SBF-1 was retained as Pbca, but the cell parameters changed after SC-SC transformation (Table S1). Ca-SBF-1 revealed a shortening in the a (from 21.40 to 20.01 Å) and b (from 17.52 to 17.36 Å) axes and an elongation in the c (from 21.43 to 22.40 Å) axis. A shrinkage of the cell volume (from 8036 to 7780 Å3) was also observed. A careful structural examination and a comparison of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 suggested that structure deformation was reflected in two aspects. One is a small amount of distortion over the spirobifluorene ring, with a change of the dihedral angle from 89.5 to 87.4° (a). The other is a significant change in the coordination geometry of the Ca2+ ions. In the new calcium oxocluster, hexacoordinated Ca1 takes a distorted octahedral geometry, and octacoordinated Ca2 exhibits a distorted dodecahedral geometry (b). Much longer Ca⋅⋅⋅Ca distances were observed, i.e., Ca1⋅⋅⋅Ca2 distances from 3.630(1) to 3.715(2) Å, Ca1⋅⋅⋅Ca1 distances from 4.176(1) to 4.318(2) Å, and Ca2⋅⋅⋅Ca2 distances from 10.856(2) to 11.163(3) Å. The elongated oxocluster could be considered as two separate Ca2+ dimers, and with this new node, the whole framework could be described as an infinite 3D 5,5-connected 2-nodal net, which represents a new topology with a point symbol {45.65} (Figure S7). The solvent-accessible volume was reduced from 45% (Ca-SBF) to 39% (Ca-SBF-1), suggesting a slight structure shrinkage. The aperture sizes of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 were calculated as 5.47 and 5.27 Å by Poreblazer (Table S2).

elements.content: Structure comparison between Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1: (a) change of the dihedral angle; (b) change of the coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text: 2  Structure comparison between Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1: (a) change of the dihedral angle; (b) change of the coordination geometry.

elements.content: The bulk phase purities of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Figure S9). The difference between the PXRD patterns and intensities of the experimental and simulated Ca-SBF-1 may be explained by the incomplete structural model in which the locations of the solvent molecules were not considered after the SQUEEZE route. Variable-temperature PXRD showed thermal stability of Ca-SBF up to 300 °C (Figure S10). A preliminary assessment on the water stability of Ca-SBF showed that the crystallinity was retained (Figure S11g).
elements.clean_text: The bulk phase purities of Ca-SBF and Ca-SBF-1 were confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD; Figure S9). The difference between the PXRD patterns and intensities of the experimental and simulated Ca-SBF-1 may be explained by the incomplete structural model in which the locations of the solvent molecules were not considered after the SQUEEZE route. Variable-temperature PXRD showed thermal stability of Ca-SBF up to 300 °C (Figure S10). A preliminary assessment on the water stability of Ca-SBF showed that the crystallinity was retained (Figure S11g).

elements.content: Preservation of the crystallinity after solvent exchange encouraged us to test the permanent porosity of Ca-SBF by gas adsorption measurements. N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating a microporous nature of Ca-SBF (a). The N2 uptake reaches a saturation of 109 cm3·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.99, with a pore volume of 0.17 cm3·g–1 (lower than the calculated value; Table S2). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are calculated to be 378 and 444 m2·g–1, respectively (Figure S12a,b), which are lower than those reported for 2D and 3D SBF-based MOFs. The calculated pore sizes by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method demonstrated a narrow distribution around 5.0–6.0 Å (Figure S12c). The crystallinity of Ca-SBF is maintained after BET measurements, as indicated by PXRD (Figure S9e). The reversible adsorption–desorption isotherms of CO2 on activated Ca-SBF show an uptake of 44.9 cm3·g–1 (2.0 mmol·g–1, 8.8 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar and a decreasing uptake of 35.0 cm3·g–1 (1.6 mmol·g–1, 6.9 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar (b). The uptake at 298 K is higher than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, which may be explained by the existence of more open metal sites in the framework of activated Ca-SBF. At very low coverage, the isosteric adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of CO2 was calculated to be 16.6 kJ·mol–1 (Figure S12d), which is lower than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, indicating a moderate interaction between CO2 and the framework.
elements.clean_text: Preservation of the crystallinity after solvent exchange encouraged us to test the permanent porosity of Ca-SBF by gas adsorption measurements. N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating a microporous nature of Ca-SBF (a). The N2 uptake reaches a saturation of 109 cm3⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.99, with a pore volume of 0.17 cm3⋅g-1 (lower than the calculated value; Table S2). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are calculated to be 378 and 444 m2⋅g-1, respectively (Figure S12a,b), which are lower than those reported for 2D and 3D SBF-based MOFs. The calculated pore sizes by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method demonstrated a narrow distribution around 5.0-6.0 Å (Figure S12c). The crystallinity of Ca-SBF is maintained after BET measurements, as indicated by PXRD (Figure S9e). The reversible adsorption-desorption isotherms of CO2 on activated Ca-SBF show an uptake of 44.9 cm3⋅g-1 (2.0 mmol⋅g-1, 8.8 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar and a decreasing uptake of 35.0 cm3⋅g-1 (1.6 mmol⋅g-1, 6.9 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar (b). The uptake at 298 K is higher than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, which may be explained by the existence of more open metal sites in the framework of activated Ca-SBF. At very low coverage, the isosteric adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of CO2 was calculated to be 16.6 kJ⋅mol-1 (Figure S12d), which is lower than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, indicating a moderate interaction between CO2 and the framework.

elements.content: (a) N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 77 K for Ca-SBF. (b) CO2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K for Ca-SBF.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 77 K for Ca-SBF. (b) CO2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at 273 and 298 K for Ca-SBF.

elements.content: The regular nanopores, medium surface area, and hydrophobic inner wall of Ca-SBF gave us an impetus to study the sensing properties of Ca-SBF toward VOCs, which could lead to long-term health effects and irreversible damage to human bodies. VOC sensing properties of Ca-SBF have been investigated by a QCM transducer. The QCM sensor modified with Ca-SBF shows a selective response to toluene upon exposure to different vapors, as shown in a. When a QCM sensor is exposed to different vapors (100 ppm), it shows a decrease in frequencies, i.e., −3240 Hz to toluene, −1350 Hz to ethanol, −886 Hz to acetone, and −330 Hz to benzene. After the introduction of 100 ppm toluene vapor, the frequency of the QCM decreased quickly and achieved the highest value of −3240 Hz. When N2 was introduced as a carrier gas, the signal rapidly returned to the initial state (b). The response–recovery cycle is less than 1 min and indicates the reversibility of the sensing process. The good reproducibility of the QCM sensor was confirmed by the successive recording of three response–recovery cycles (b). The concentration-dependent responses to toluene vapor exhibit an increasing linear relationship in the range of 0–60 ppm and gradually reach a saturation above 100 ppm (Figure S13a). Given a concentration increase of 40 ppm versus a frequency decrease of 1600 Hz (1 ppm vs 40 Hz) in the linear region of concentration-dependent responses, the detection limit of the QCM sensor was estimated at the ppm level according to the signal-to-noise (S/N) ratio conventions of IUPAC (3/1). The selectivity and sensitivity of a Ca-SBF-modified QCM sensor are comparable with those of other reported MOF-based QCM sensors (Table S3 and Figure S14). High selectivity and sensitivity toward toluene vapor may be ascribed to the synergistic effect of the size selectivity of regular nanopores and weak intermolecular interactions between toluene vapors and the framework. The proposed explanation was further verified by QCM responses upon exposure to benzene and substituted benzenes (Figure S13b). The frequency changes induced by substituted benzenes are obviously larger than that of benzene, indicating the important contribution of σ–π interactions between the alkyl group of substituted benzenes and the aromatic rings of the framework in combination with π–π interactions. A downward trend in the frequency changes was observed from toluene to mesitylene, suggesting that toluene with a diameter of 5.68 Å would be well-matched with the pore aperture of the framework (5.0–6.0 Å).

elements.content: In conclusion, we have presented a new 3D SBF-based MOF with permanent porosity and flu topology. The resultant Ca-SBF could undergo a SC–SC transformation to Ca-SBF-1 and exhibit CO2 adsorption properties. The sensing performance of Ca-SBF toward VOCs was evaluated by a QCM transducer, and a Ca-SBF-modified QCM sensor showed selective response to toluene vapor. We have revealed that SBF-based MOFs could be a new kind of promising candidate for gas storage and sensing materials.
elements.clean_text: In conclusion, we have presented a new 3D SBF-based MOF with permanent porosity and flu topology. The resultant Ca-SBF could undergo a SC-SC transformation to Ca-SBF-1 and exhibit CO2 adsorption properties. The sensing performance of Ca-SBF toward VOCs was evaluated by a QCM transducer, and a Ca-SBF-modified QCM sensor showed selective response to toluene vapor. We have revealed that SBF-based MOFs could be a new kind of promising candidate for gas storage and sensing materials.

Experimental details, synthesis and characterization, crystallographic data, TGA, PXRD, gas adsorption, QCM sensor fabrication, and additional figures and details (PDF)

CCDC 1570721-1570722 contain the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif, or by emailing data_request@ccdc.cam.ac.uk, or by contacting The Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK; fax: +44 1223 336033.

cln_elements.content: Preservation of the crystallinity after solvent exchange encouraged us to test the permanent porosity of Ca-SBF by gas adsorption measurements. N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating a microporous nature of Ca-SBF (a). The N2 uptake reaches a saturation of 109 cm3·g–1 at P/P 0 = 0.99, with a pore volume of 0.17 cm3·g–1 (lower than the calculated value; Table S2). The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are calculated to be 378 and 444 m2·g–1, respectively (Figure S12a,b), which are lower than those reported for 2D and 3D SBF-based MOFs. The calculated pore sizes by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method demonstrated a narrow distribution around 5.0–6.0 Å (Figure S12c). The crystallinity of Ca-SBF is maintained after BET measurements, as indicated by PXRD (Figure S9e). The reversible adsorption–desorption isotherms of CO2 on activated Ca-SBF show an uptake of 44.9 cm3·g–1 (2.0 mmol·g–1, 8.8 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar and a decreasing uptake of 35.0 cm3·g–1 (1.6 mmol·g–1, 6.9 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar (b). The uptake at 298 K is higher than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, which may be explained by the existence of more open metal sites in the framework of activated Ca-SBF. At very low coverage, the isosteric adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of CO2 was calculated to be 16.6 kJ·mol–1 (Figure S12d), which is lower than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, indicating a moderate interaction between CO2 and the framework.
cln_elements.clean_text: Preservation of the crystallinity after solvent exchange encouraged us to test the permanent porosity of Ca-SBF by gas adsorption measurements. N2 adsorption measurements at 77 K show a reversible type I isotherm, indicating a microporous nature of Ca-SBF (a). The N2 uptake reaches a saturation of 109 cm3⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 0.99, with a pore volume of 0.17 cm3⋅g-1 (lower than the calculated value; Table S2). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Langmuir surface areas are calculated to be 378 and 444 m2⋅g-1, respectively (Figure S12a,b), which are lower than those reported for 2D and 3D SBF-based MOFs. The calculated pore sizes by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) method demonstrated a narrow distribution around 5.0-6.0 Å (Figure S12c). The crystallinity of Ca-SBF is maintained after BET measurements, as indicated by PXRD (Figure S9e). The reversible adsorption-desorption isotherms of CO2 on activated Ca-SBF show an uptake of 44.9 cm3⋅g-1 (2.0 mmol⋅g-1, 8.8 wt %) at 273 K and 1 bar and a decreasing uptake of 35.0 cm3⋅g-1 (1.6 mmol⋅g-1, 6.9 wt %) at 298 K and 1 bar (b). The uptake at 298 K is higher than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, which may be explained by the existence of more open metal sites in the framework of activated Ca-SBF. At very low coverage, the isosteric adsorption enthalpy (Q st) of CO2 was calculated to be 16.6 kJ⋅mol-1 (Figure S12d), which is lower than those of reported 2D SBF-based MOFs, indicating a moderate interaction between CO2 and the framework.

cln_elements.content: Structure illustration of Ca-SBF: (a) unique calcium oxocluster; (b) capped octahedral geometry of Ca1 and pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry of Ca2; (c) zigzag-shaped oxocluster; (d) 8-connected oxocluster; (e) 4-connected ligand; (f) 3D framework viewed along the b axis; (g) flu topology.

metadata.title:
A 3D Calcium Spirobifluorene Metal–Organic
Framework: Single-Crystal-to-Single-Crystal Transformation and Toluene
Detection by a Quartz Crystal Microbalance  Sensor
